awd_titl_txt: Simulating Dense Gas in Active Galactic Nuclei, Tidal Disruption Events, and Supernovae
awd_abstract_narration:
Part 1

Astronomy is an observational, not experimental, science.  We cannot go to a star and directly measure its temperature, density, or how it makes energy.  Rather, we discover these things by careful study of their light at different colors.  Complex interactions between atoms and molecules produce light.  The PIs are developing a large computer program, Cloudy, to predict this.  Cloudy solves the complex equations of quantum mechanics and relativity.  Astronomers use Cloudy to simulate what is happening in a distant star or galaxy and predict the emitted light.  This is compared with what is seen through telescopes.  This comparison makes it possible to understand what is happening.  Cloudy is freely available and is among the more widely used codes in astronomy.

The PIs will do two types of broader impact.  They organize international workshops showing how to apply Cloudy to research projects.  The Co-PI, a native of Spain, will visit local K-12 schools with large Hispanic populations.  He does Spanish language talks and presentations.  Hispanic students and their families visit the university for astronomy talks and viewing with the MacAdam Student Observatory.

Part 2
 
Astronomy is an observational, not experimental, science.  We cannot directly measure the temperature, density, or energy source for a star or galaxy.  We discover these things by quantitative spectroscopy, the careful study of the observed spectrum.  Astronomical sources are usually far from equilibrium.  Their spectra depend on a number of thermal, plasma, chemical, and condensed matter processes.  Analytical solutions are not possible.  The code Cloudy solves all of this, numerically, to predict the spectrum.  These predictions are compared that observations to infer properties of a star or galaxy.  Cloudy is one of the more widely used theory codes in astrophysics with more than 300 papers citing its documentation per year.

Cloudy has long solved these problems using available computers and atomic data.  The simulations can be improved as computers become more powerful and the atomic data more accurate.  We are developing techniques to improve modeling of the dense gas found near black holes or exploding stars.  A full treatment of the "Rydberg levels," the highly excited orbits of electrons around ions, is the key improvement.  This work will have an influence well beyond this project because of Cloudy's broad community use.

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual merit: Astronomy is an observational science, not an experimental science. We can only look and cannot touch. But we have an advantage over laboratory sciences since we have a time machine; we can take advantage of the finite speed of light to look back in time.

This project developed the theoretical and computational tools to understand what happened far from the Earth, using only the light we receive from "out there." The astronomical systems are highly disequilibrium so thermodynamic concepts have little meaning. Their physical state is determined by the microphysics, which must be simulated in detail. This is a challenging problem at the forefront of atomic, molecular, and computational physics.

We are developing the spectral simulation code Cloudy to solve all this physics self-consistently and autonomously. Astronomers can postulate the physical properties of a cloud far from the Earth, then use Cloudy to predict its spectrum. This can be compared with observations, and the properties of the postulated cloud adjusted to come into agreement with observations. In this way, Cloudy is a starship that allows astronomers to explore the universe through spectroscopy.

Cloudy, born in 1978, was one of the first open-source theoretical codes in astrophysics. During the course of this grant, Nature Astronomy named Cloudy the first of its Codes of Honour in their Access Code series, acknowledging its role in astronomical research. The attached figure, derived from bibliometric information in the Astrophysics Data System, shows the number of citations to the code's documentation as a function of time. Today, the astronomical community cites Cloudy in about 400 papers per year. This was made possible by forty years of continuous support by NSF.

The code's C++ source, documentation, extensive test suite, and a large database of atomic and molecular data are all freely accessible in a GitLab repository maintained at nublado.org. Maintaining a large code requires a significant amount of infrastructure work. The code had lived in an SVN repository hosted by a commercial web provider. Over the course of this project, that provider went out of business, and it became necessary to move to a new repository. We used this as an opportunity to move the project from SVN, an older source code control system no longer widely used, to GIT, the de factor standard in astronomy today. The University of Kentucky created a GitLab repository for our use. Today, Cloudy and its supporting infrastructure are entirely openly accessible in GIT format. This migration took a significant human effort but made the project far more future-proof.

We published sixty-eight journal papers over the course of this project. These applied Cloudy to various astronomical problems, including events occurring near supermassive black holes in the centers of galaxies and studies of how stars produce the elements that make up the Earth. Investigations like these ensure that Cloudy is developed to address current topics in astronomical research.

Broader impact: Festival del Espacio. Hispanics are a significant part of our local population and are underrepresented in STEM fields. Our project postdoc, Dr Francisco Guzman, is a native of Spain, and he presented a remarkable opportunity to reach Hispanic students and introduce them to STEM and the University.  We created a Festival del Espacio, an annual Spanish-language science festival focusing on astronomical observations for elementary and middle school students and the general public. Our three Festivals were a mix of hands-on demonstrations and organized activities, using graduate students as facilitators, with a keynote talk by a native Spanish speaker. Pre and post-event tests were given to participants to judge results. The Festivals attracted between 150 to 200 attendees for each event.
